ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Section

The live lectures were all recorded during the synchronous meetings so that we could go back to them later. The class size was quite small, closer to the size of a seminar, but lectures were mostly times to take notes and answer prompts presented by Prof. Kreuzer. Discussion section was the time for more free-flowing conversation and less note-taking.

biweekly live zoom lectures
weekly live discussion section
weekly live virtual discussion sections, in addition to live virtual lectures
We had a live virtual lecture that was also available as a recording. There was also a virtual discussion section.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge of composers from Beethoven to the present day along with literary and artistic movements and harmonic procedures of the times

I gained significant knowledge of Western art music, beginning with the era of Beethoven, up until the present day with the final class culminating with a discussion with Missy Mazzoli. The course is quite detailed, with biographical histories of composers/eminent figures of significance, socio-political context, and musical analyses of works by the composers that are discussed. These analyses are meant to highlight elements of pieces that are characteristics of the era/school in which they were composed.
I gained a thorough understanding of western classical music from the early 1800's to the present!

I learned about historical periods, trends, and themes relevant to Western Art Music, prominent composers from each major era, and their bodies of work. I was able to practice and improve my musical analysis skills through written analysis assignments and my ability to identify salient aspects of different classical genres through listening assignments.

I gained a lot of knowledge on the ideological themes and musical changes that occurred over time with the western art-music tradition. It was especially interesting to learn about the different perceptions of program music and absolute music as well as the different philosophical ideas about the trajectory of western art-music.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Really interesting!! Gundula did such a good job of making the material interesting and applicable. I loved learning about and listening to the music in class. No weaknesses to say

The course's main strength was its professor, Prof. Kreuzer. She delivered every lecture with an air of excitement, organization, and charisma which made the course very enjoyable to engage with. The slides she displayed were all very well-made, and her infographics/annotations of musical characteristics on scores were highly detailed and easy to comprehend. 
I wouldn't call it a weakness necessarily, but the course is so incredibly chock-full of details and information which, when it is time for the 2 factual quizzes, can make it quite burdensome to figure out what to prioritize when studying.

This course is amazing! Professor Kreutzer is an amazing professor and an engaging lecturer! The content was so much fun to read and listen to! I'm not sure how necessary the sections were, but given the online classes, they were a nice way to discuss the content.

The biggest strength of this course is Professor Kreuzer herself, who is passionate, obviously knowledgeable, and an excellent lecturer. Her enthusiasm for the subject shone through even, even in a virtual setting. The material was fascinating and comprehensive. The readings, mainly sourced from Taruskin's Oxford History of Western Music, are also very engaging, and the Taruskin probably helped me think more rigorously about the production of historical narratives and historiographic methodology more than any history class I've taken at Yale. However, the tests (two factual quizzes and two listening quizzes) were very tough, with multi-part, very specific questions and a panic-inducingly short completion time. Factual quiz questions also didn't ask about composer biographies, despite those being discussed in both lecture and readings. Without access to recordings of the lectures, I would've found it very difficult to study (and I don't think I take terrible notes!), especially since lecture slides weren't made available. Essentially, I would've liked to know at the outset what type of material was going to be quizzed so as to focus my studying and notes. In that vein, studying was made much easier when around halfway through the semester, Professor Krezuer began including detailed summary lecture slides of a composer's stylistic features, which were big components of the quizzes. This was a game-changer and really helped me do better in the second half of the semester.

I think the first factual quiz caught some of us by surprise, and there was less guidance up front about what we should prioritize in our studying, but this was addressed in time for the second factual quiz. The use of a Spotify playlist to host all music relevant to the course was very convenient and made studying/engaging with course material much easier.

The timeline of the assessments and writing assignments is helpful for keeping up with the material. I think it would be helpful to have more streamlined reading assignments or readings that were different from what was talked about during the lecture because sometimes the readings felt redundant.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It would be better obviously if we could listen to music in person, but it was the best it could have been

The course was very well-organized despite the limitations of virtual learning. Prof. Kreuzer's slides and audio examples were delivered almost always without technical difficulties (and in the times that there were issues, she was able to solve them without much delay). 

These are not issues that Prof. Kreuzer may be able to address more than they are technical limitations of Zoom, but two things that could be improved are (1) the framerate when screen-sharing videos (they are almost always around 1-2 frames per second)--perhaps it would be best to focus on audio so as to not be distracted by the choppy visuals--and (2) when speaking while a musical example is playing, the audio cuts out and makes it impossible to hear what is being said and decreases the quality of the music being played.
The lectures were overall really engaging live on Zoom. At times, there were technical difficulties, but this is to be expected in this situation!

Technical difficulties with screen sharing/connectivity often ate into class time, causing us to end late quite consistently. I'm not sure how this could be improved other than everyone becoming more well-adjusted to the virtual format.
Having the lecture recorded and accessible online in addition to having it live was a very helpful aspect of virtual learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!! Such a great class for anybody interested in music. You really learn about the massive transformations that took place in music over the past 200 years
Yes! The course is taught very well, and the content is quite enjoyable to learn, especially for students interested in or with a background in classical music.
YES! If you are interested in western classical music history!

I'd recommend this course to anyone who is passionate about or looking to expand their knowledge of classical music. Proficiency in music theory helps greatly. I could imagine it being difficult for someone who is not very passionate about classical music to enjoy the course, but either way the material is interesting and engaging.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another music student interested in learning about 19th and 20th-century music history. The class was very insightful and provided a lot of context that can be useful in other music theory courses.
